document.title: Science Content Standards for California Public Schools Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve

23F117F4A4A64FEFBBC5E9CD3DC81F7E.description: Know that when an observation does not agree with an accepted scientific theory, the observation is sometimes mistaken or fraudulent (e.g., the Piltdown Man fossil or unidentified flying objects) and that the theory is sometimes wrong (e.g., the Ptolemaic model of the movement of the Sun, Moon, and planets).

11AC32C7F1834B1AAC972CAEC4743EFB.description: Investigate a science-based societal issue by researching the literature, analyzing data, and communicating the findings. Examples of issues include irradiation of food, cloning of animals by somatic cell nuclear transfer, choice of energy sources, and land and water use decisions in California.

59CFC089FE79423FB21E00C26E8305CC.description: Analyze situations and solve problems that require combining and applying concepts from more than one area of science.

103144F326BA41709F194309B3DCEB4D.description: Recognize the cumulative nature of scientific evidence.

DC69F0EEA14E40AE9634964410BBC475.description: Recognize the issues of statistical variability and the need for controlled tests.

E68216215F7F4DC0ADC5CFEA241B0998.description:
Analyze the locations, sequences, or time intervals that are characteristic of
natural phenomena (e.g., relative ages of rocks, locations of planets over time, and succession of species in an ecosystem).

C6D1AA5FB4C448DDB2920E668F474626.description: Read and interpret topographic and geologic maps.

2433E046AF8E4B18BF2D3728B8102928.description: Recognize the usefulness and limitations of models and theories as scientific representations of reality.

84812217CABC4E41917FC5C200D1F956.description: Distinguish between hypothesis and theory as scientific terms.

ABBB370A703543A39A9DE15B5435148C.description: Solve scientific problems by using quadratic equations and simple trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions.

49933B1BFCBE4386B10A45E6DD0435DB.description: Formulate explanations by using logic and evidence.

9C8C9C8074654CAC8AC9C5CF7815EF97.description: Identify possible reasons for inconsistent results, such as sources of error or uncontrolled conditions.

00AE20C66C74488CB06FAE9DA2B8721D.description: Identify and communicate sources of unavoidable experimental error.

EC63885E1A9241759BB53009429EE7C8.description: Select and use appropriate tools and technology (such as computer-linked probes, spreadsheets, and graphing calculators) to perform tests, collect data, analyze relationships, and display data.

35CE64064D4D42E4B3E674DE23575B0D.description: Scientific progress is made by asking meaningful questions and conducting careful investigations. As a basis for understanding this concept and addressing the content in the other four strands, students should develop their own questions and perform investigations. Students will:

953EA26A0ED64008BAA52A483DFB8018.description: Students know how to analyze published geologic hazard maps of California and know how to use the map’s information to identify evidence of geologic events of the past and predict geologic changes in the future.

E076B9FF3CFE45D2B7EC3F65174EBAF2.description: Students know the importance of water to society, the origins of California’s fresh water, and the relationship between supply and need.

9D9EE490012A4A7BADD64CA8D582AD93.description: Students know the principal natural hazards in different California regions and the geologic basis of those hazards.

7AC4933A0B12410F85A649AF71DA7386.description: Students know the resources of major economic importance in California and their relation to California’s geology.

BE4A6E7E1BC94A7B9C5446B3B606C571.description: The geology of California underlies the state’s wealth of natural resources as well as its natural hazards. As a basis for understanding this concept:

6C97202912CF45BC9B97B702870C424D.description:
Students know the location of the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, its role in
absorbing ultraviolet radiation, and the way in which this layer varies both naturally and in response to human activities.

1D8DB7D1FBBC468C8355BD6CA2D47171.description: Students know how the composition of Earth’s atmosphere has evolved over geologic time and know the effect of outgassing, the variations of carbon dioxide concentration, and the origin of atmospheric oxygen.

6BE299354A424EECA42B7BDA022D97D2.description: Students know the thermal structure and chemical composition of the atmosphere.

649E8C43CC9E4078A6501E15226B7BF2.description: Life has changed Earth’s atmosphere, and changes in the atmosphere affect conditions for life. As a basis for understanding this concept:

ABDC29161B6D44BF899A63EF97C3EE80.description: Structure and Composition of the Atmosphere

F9BCD3D26D264324A52AF14B8AEA489F.description: Students know the relative residence times and flow characteristics of carbon in and out of its different reservoirs.

296F4F328BE44A098BC0C5DF16A3BB70.description: Students know the movement of matter among reservoirs is driven by Earth’s internal and external sources of energy.

070468B58ABA461B901005A34E2E42EA.description: Students know the global carbon cycle: the different physical and chemical forms of carbon in the atmosphere, oceans, biomass, fossil fuels, and the movement of carbon among these reservoirs.

A0138AD440BE43769E7AB7005EB3D028.description: Students know the carbon cycle of photosynthesis and respiration and the nitrogen cycle.

8412B2C1BD7746FDA3C7520DEF716F70.description:
Each element on Earth moves among reservoirs, which exist in the solid earth, in oceans, in the atmosphere, and within and among organisms as part of biogeochemical
cycles. As a basis for understanding this concept:

F5996FB833034715AA59A610558B2AC6.description: Students know how computer models are used to predict the effects of the increase in greenhouse gases on climate for the planet as a whole and for specific regions.

A0EB4C67D084457195B14465FB469020.description: Students know how Earth’s climate has changed over time, corresponding to changes in Earth’s geography, atmospheric composition, and other factors, such as solar radiation and plate movement.

6164C86FF2CC46EA8C80E4DE5BC89A51.description: Students know the effects on climate of latitude, elevation, topography, and proximity to large bodies of water and cold or warm ocean currents.

DF75679F004E41A8B27F0580FD082819.description: Students know weather (in the short run) and climate (in the long run) involve the transfer of energy into and out of the atmosphere.

56F8C08EF8B74D9A9B9105337DAC565E.description: Climate is the long-term average of a region’s weather and depends on many factors. As a basis for understanding this concept:

2948F35DC7494499BAB12CCF7BA77799.description:
Students know features of the ENSO (El Niño southern oscillation) cycle in terms of
sea-surface and air temperature variations across the Pacific and some climatic results of this cycle.

D6FCA94065FD489A8CE0A35DE8C04217.description: Students know the interaction of wind patterns, ocean currents, and mountain ranges results in the global pattern of latitudinal bands of rain forests and deserts.

3C9481ADECFB40C584AEE2EBF740DE7E.description: Students know rain forests and deserts on Earth are distributed in bands at specific latitudes.

5A7E0856E50A4648BD37CE910863FE74.description: Students know properties of ocean water, such as temperature and salinity, can be used to explain the layered structure of the oceans, the generation of horizontal and vertical ocean currents, and the geographic distribution of marine organisms.

205A3E1CE9CB4609BFCFA2A0F06F4B5E.description: Students know the origin and effects of temperature inversions.

F5B03DE26C714F719F436FC4E5ACD304.description: Students know the relationship between the rotation of Earth and the circular motions of ocean currents and air in pressure centers.

C0D8132B5FE24A1587FE14F689A2F3D1.description: Students know how differential heating of Earth results in circulation patterns in the atmosphere and oceans that globally distribute the heat.

49E2244AE95444A5861BCDBD21756B20.description: Heating of Earth’s surface and atmosphere by the sun drives convection within the atmosphere and oceans, producing winds and ocean currents. As a basis for understanding this concept:

6AE21B723AB64280A6DBB28B7527E0CF.description: Students know the differing greenhouse conditions on Earth, Mars, and Venus; the origins of those conditions; and the climatic consequences of each.

07C891C30F8F4C78B291F478B41A31C5.description: Students know the different atmospheric gases that absorb the Earth’s thermal radiation and the mechanism and significance of the greenhouse effect.

59BFDD0C3E6941918BF4771B3E7A3031.description: Students know the fate of incoming solar radiation in terms of reflection, absorption, and photosynthesis.

296252E21CF04E8CBFB304A38A7D7F6C.description: Students know the relative amount of incoming solar energy compared with Earth’s internal energy and the energy used by society.

CDDBB455C5BB4B498DB25D77C12FCCC8.description: Energy enters the Earth system primarily as solar radiation and eventually escapes as heat. As a basis for understanding this concept:

5468D41C2E2B4FD4A0B54930373075C3.description: Students know the explanation for the location and properties of volcanoes that are due to hot spots and the explanation for those that are due to subduction.

120FE4B8DE2146F99EDD2D25FC244328.description: Students know there are two kinds of volcanoes: one kind with violent eruptions producing steep slopes and the other kind with voluminous lava flows producing gentle slopes.

AA754C39204B4F9AB8BED8631790B024.description: Students know why and how earthquakes occur and the scales used to measure their intensity and magnitude.

1E0472D90A89444BAF9BFEC8889B3BB9.description: Students know how to explain the properties of rocks based on the physical and chemical conditions in which they formed, including plate tectonic processes.

B7085AB0D5574588AA9A85119F3D6030.description: Students know the principal structures that form at the three different kinds of plate boundaries.

7AABF6EB8E644D53A5D2659F793ACFA8.description: Students know features of the ocean floor (magnetic patterns, age, and sea-floor topography) provide evidence of plate tectonics.

BEC8A556C3844601BF519B68FAB87E6A.description: Plate tectonics operating over geologic time has changed the patterns of land, sea, and mountains on Earth’s surface. As the basis for understanding this concept:

22409E62D5904727BDAFEC07DA8F4AB9.description: Students know how the red-shift from distant galaxies and the cosmic background radiation provide evidence for the “big bang” model that suggests that the universe has been expanding for 10 to 20 billion years.

1ACC1D288EE441F6A16C19228A43466F.description: Students know the evidence indicating that the color, brightness, and evolution of a star are determined by a balance between gravitational collapse and nuclear fusion.

61F59DE1B3824C2DB5AA135F3FF8EF56.description: Students know accelerators boost subatomic particles to energy levels that simulate conditions in the stars and in the early history of the universe before stars formed.

7A9FF1A64B124C2AB334675E39845B95.description: Students know that stars differ in their life cycles and that visual, radio, and X-ray telescopes may be used to collect data that reveal those differences.

323EBFDFD3244989A887DF53D4DE5DC0.description: Students know the evidence indicating that all elements with an atomic number greater than that of lithium have been formed by nuclear fusion in stars.

5DE821B80B8445ECBF9A55E893E54B83.description: Students know galaxies are made of billions of stars and comprise most of the visible mass of the universe.

46629A40EFEC4D62AC9CECD7398F4D5A.description: Students know the solar system is located in an outer edge of the disc-shaped Milky Way galaxy, which spans 100,000 light years. b. Students know galaxies are made of billions of stars and

2935CD1831C24291AB22DDAB6060DD32.description: Earth-based and space-based astronomy reveal the structure, scale, and changes in stars, galaxies, and the universe over time. As a basis for understanding this concept:

2174D2F5288944DB9AAC5FDA9A976043.description: Students know the evidence for the existence of planets orbiting other stars.

F972ADD870004101BF4C96195BBAF2EE.description: Students know the evidence for the dramatic effects that asteroid impacts have had in shaping the surface of planets and their moons and in mass extinctions of life on Earth.

A9261BF0F01F4030AD0DCB2C88690960.description: Students know the Sun is a typical star and is powered by nuclear reactions, primarily the fusion of hydrogen to form helium.

182A627C4FC341DDB5B13C05C6980924.description: Students know the evidence indicating that the planets are much closer to Earth than the stars are.

AB5E94991DC3474698715E8AE29727BD.description: Students know the evidence from geological studies of Earth and other planets suggest that the early Earth was very different from Earth today.

5433079457E2423A8DB72A7D320FF70B.description: Students know the evidence from Earth and moon rocks indicates that the solar system was formed from a nebular cloud of dust and gas approximately 4.6 billion years ago.

68552632F06540A994F7C1C58FD7F374.description: Students know how the differences and similarities among the sun, the terrestrial planets, and the gas planets may have been established during the formation of the solar system.

018D156DF04549E88DDEB885327A956A.description: Astronomy and planetary exploration reveal the solar system’s structure, scale, and change over time. As a basis for understanding this concept:
